  • Used in vesiculobullous disorders like pemphigus
  • Nikolsky sign rather than Nikolsky test.
  • Involves applying tangential pressure to separate epidermis
  • Tests for acantholysis in epidermis 
  • Not relevant for scaly plaques of psoriasis

 

 

Option C. Asboe Hansen test

 

  • Variant of bulla spread sign
  • Asboe Hansen sign rather than Asboe Hansen test.
  • Used in vesiculobullous disorders
  • Involves applying perpendicular pressure to center of intact bulla
  • Not applicable for psoriatic plaques

 

 

Option D. Patch test

 

  • Investigation of choice for allergic contact dermatitis
  • Tests for type IV hypersensitivity reaction
  • Not indicated for psoriasis diagnosis
  • Used to identify specific allergens

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Grattage test, demonstrating candle wax scaling, bulkeley membrane, and pinpoint bleeding (Auspitz sign), is the diagnostic test for psoriasis.

choices.text: Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

questions.text: Topical application of Mitomycin C is commonly used in the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

 

Explanation:


Mitomycin-C is used post-operatively in laryngotracheal reconstruction to prevent adhesions and fibrosis. In the treatment of subglottic stenosis, after procedures such as laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage grafts or resection of stenosed segments, Mitomycin-C is specifically applied to prevent scar tissue formation that could lead to recurrent stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic management of Angiofibroma: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used in the management of angiofibroma. These tumors are typically managed with surgical excision, preoperative embolization, or radiation in some cases.

 

Option B. Management of Sturge-Weber syndrome: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used for Sturge-Weber syndrome. This vascular condition typically requires different management approaches.

 

Option C. Treatment of Skull base osteomyelitis: This is incorrect. Skull base osteomyelitis treatment typically involves long-term antibiotics and sometimes surgical debridement, but Mitomycin-C application is not part of the standard treatment protocol.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mitomycin-C is an antifibrotic agent applied topically during laryngotracheal procedures to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and prevent adhesions and stenosis formation, making it particularly valuable in the management of laryngotracheal stenosis.

choices.text: Lawful under Article 21 of the constitution
Unlawful under Article 21 of the constitution
Lawful under Article 19 of the constitution
Unlawful under Article 19 of the constitution

questions.text: Force feeding of prisoners on hunger strikes is? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Unlawful under Article 21 of the constitution

 

Explanation:

 

Force feeding of prisoners on hunger strikes is unlawful under Article 21 of the constitution. The Declaration of Malta specifically addresses hunger strikes and establishes that "respect for individual autonomy restrains physicians from intervening when a valid and informed refusal has been made." Article 21 protects the right to life and personal liberty, which includes the right to refuse medical treatment and preserves bodily autonomy.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A (Lawful under Article 21): This contradicts the principle that Article 21 protects personal liberty, making force feeding against one's will unlawful.
  • Option C (Lawful under Article 19): Article 19 concerns freedom of speech and expression, not bodily autonomy or medical treatment, making this irrelevant to force feeding scenarios.
  • Option D (Unlawful under Article 19): While correctly stating force feeding is unlawful, it incorrectly attributes this to Article 19 rather than Article 21, which is the constitutional provision that actually protects bodily integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Malta provides ethical guidelines for physicians regarding hunger strikers, emphasizing that even when a physician believes intervention would benefit the patient, respect for autonomy must prevail when an informed refusal has been made.

questions.text: The "Carpet Tack Sign" is observed in which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE)

 

  • The Carpet Tack Sign (also called Tin Tack Sign or Cat Tongue Sign) is a characteristic finding in Discoid Lupus Erythematosus. 
  • When the adherent scale from a DLE lesion is removed, the undersurface shows keratotic spikes that have occupied the dilated pilosebaceous canals. 
  • This creates a pattern resembling the underside of a carpet tack.

 

 

  • DLE typically presents as well-demarcated, discoid erythematous plaques with adherent scales on sun-exposed areas like face, scalp, and ears. 
  • The lesions characteristically show follicular plugging, central scarring with depigmentation, and peripheral hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pityriasis Versicolor:

 

  • This is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species with fine scales that don't demonstrate the carpet tack sign. 

 

Option C. Psoriasis:

 

  • Though psoriasis has silvery scales, they are loose and don't adhere tightly to the skin. 
  • When removed, they show Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding) but not keratotic projections on the undersurface of scales.

 

Option D. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Features polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules with Wickham's striae. 
  • It doesn't typically have adherent scales that would demonstrate the carpet tack phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The Carpet Tack Sign is pathognomonic for Discoid Lupus Erythematosus, where removal of adherent scales reveals keratotic projections on the undersurface that had occupied dilated follicular openings.

questions.text: A diabetic elderly man presents with dyspnea and pedal edema. A chest X-ray (CXR) shows an enlarged heart with rales. Echo reveals a low ejection fraction (EF). Which of the following treatments will delay the progression of cardiac disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a medication that belongs to the class of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors. Although it is primarily used to manage diabetes by promoting glucose excretion through urine, it has been found to have significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly those with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Mechanism of Action in Heart Failure: Empagliflozin improves cardiac outcomes through several mechanisms:

 

  • Reduction in preload and afterload: By promoting diuresis and natriuresis, empagliflozin reduces the volume overload, which is beneficial in heart failure.
  • Improvement in myocardial metabolism: It shifts myocardial substrate utilization from glucose to ketone bodies, which is more energy-efficient for the failing heart.
  • Reduction in cardiac fibrosis and inflammation: Empagliflozin has anti-inflammatory and anti-fibrotic effects, which help in reducing cardiac remodeling and progression of heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrochlorothiazide: This is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to manage hypertension and mild fluid retention. However, it does not have significant benefits in delaying the progression of heart failure.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic used for symptomatic relief of fluid overload in heart failure but does not specifically alter the progression of the disease.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin is used in heart failure to improve symptoms and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, but it does not have a mortality benefit or significantly delay the progression of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, although primarily an anti-diabetic medication, has been shown to significantly benefit patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) by delaying the progression of the disease through its effects on diuresis, myocardial metabolism, and cardiac remodeling.

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

 

Muscle spindles are sensory receptors within the muscle that detect changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length. They consist of intrafusal fibers, which include both nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

 

These fibers are dynamic and are sensitive to the rate of change in muscle length (velocity of stretch). They play a crucial role in detecting muscle length changes during muscle contraction by responding to the speed at which the muscle length is changing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nuclear chain fibers: These fibers are more static and respond to the absolute length of the muscle rather than the rate of change. They are not primarily responsible for detecting changes during contraction.

 

Option C. Golgi tendon organ: This sensory receptor is located at the junction of the muscle and tendon. It monitors tension rather than length changes in the muscle. It is more involved in preventing muscle damage due to excessive force.

 

Option D. Other muscle receptor: This option is too vague. The specific receptor responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during contraction is the nuclear bag fiber.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in Opioid Substitution Therapy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Buprenorphine


Opioid Substitution Therapy (OST) is a treatment given during the maintenance phase of opioid dependence. The goal is to reduce the harm associated with opioid use, such as the risks of HIV, Hepatitis, and illegal activities related to drug procurement. In OST, opioids like buprenorphine or methadone are used to replace more harmful opioids like heroin or morphine. These substitutions help control withdrawal symptoms and prevent relapse while allowing the patient to live a more stable life. Buprenorphine, being a partial opioid agonist, is preferred because it reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms without the euphoric effects associated with other opioids, making it an effective substitute in OST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Clonidine is not used in OST because it is not an opioid. It may be used to manage withdrawal symptoms during detoxification but does not replace opioids during the maintenance phase.

 

Option B. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist, meaning it blocks the effects of opioids rather than substituting them. It can be used in the maintenance phase of opioid dependence but is not part of OST because it does not substitute one opioid for another.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used primarily to reverse opioid overdose. It is not used in OST because it does not have the substitutive effects needed for maintenance therapy in opioid dependence.

 

Educational Objective:


Opioid Substitution Therapy involves replacing a harmful opioid with a safer opioid like oral buprenorphine or methadone during the maintenance phase of treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin with increased reticulocyte count. Comment on the likely diagnosis. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemolytic anemia

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, pallor, and weakness, along with the laboratory findings of low hemoglobin and increased reticulocyte count, strongly suggests hemolytic anemia.

 

In hemolytic anemia, there is an increased destruction of red blood cells (RBCs), which leads to a compensatory increase in the production of RBCs by the bone marrow. This increased production is reflected by a higher reticulocyte count, which indicates that the bone marrow is responding to the anemia by releasing more immature red blood cells (reticulocytes) into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Typically presents with pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cells) and a low reticulocyte count, reflecting bone marrow failure.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Often shows a normal or low reticulocyte count because the bone marrow is not responding effectively due to chronic inflammation or disease.

 

Option C. Folate deficiency: Leads to megaloblastic anemia, where there is impaired DNA synthesis, resulting in large, immature RBCs with a normal or low reticulocyte count.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increased reticulocyte count in the presence of low hemoglobin suggests an overactive bone marrow, often due to hemolytic anemia, where the body compensates for increased RBC destruction by ramping up RBC production.
